metadata.title: Elaboration and study of poly(vinylidene fluoride)–anatase TiO<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf> composite membranes in photocatalytic degradation of dyes

ELABORATIONSTUDYPOLYVINYLIDENEFLUORIDEANATASETIO2COMPOSITEMEMBRANESINPHOTOCATALYTICDEGRADATIONDYES TAHIRIALAOUI O 1 Introduction 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and products 2.2 PVdF-TiO2 membrane preparation 2.3 Dye adsorption analysis and photo-degradation experiment 2.4 Characterisation of the composite membranes 2.4.1 Membrane structure analyses 2.4.2 Measurement of the overall membrane porosity 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Morphology and characteristics of composite TiO2/PVdF membranes 3.1.1 Suitability of the techniques used for preparation of TiO2-loaded membrane 3.1.2 Membrane morphology and porosity 3.2 Properties of anatase-loaded membranes in contact with dye solutions 3.2.1 TiO2/PVdF ratio for maximum rate of dye degradation 3.3 Dye adsorption 3.3.1 Effect the ethanol conditioning on dye adsorption in membranes 3.3.2 Effect of ethanol conditioning on dye adsorption and water permeation 3.3.3 Kinetics and sorption levels at equilibrium 3.4 Application of TiO2/PVdF membrane to the photocatalytic degradation of IC and BG 4 Conclusion References SLOKAR 1998 335 356 Y XI 2001 1256 1262 W DIJKSTRA 2001 547 555 M YU 2001 25 29 J TAHIRIALAOUI 2008 O LUO 2005 76 84 M IMAGE-THUMBNAIL APCATA 11870 S0926-860X(09)00070-2 10.1016/j.apcata.2009.01.032 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Chemical structure of Brilliant Green. Fig. 2 Chemical structure of Indigo Carmine. Fig. 3 SEM images of membrane surfaces: (a) PVdF membrane, (b) composite PVdF membranes of 0.5, (c) of 0.7, and (d) of 1_TiO2/PVdF wt. ratios Fig. 4 SEM images of TiO2/PVdF membrane cross-sections (c) composite membranes of 0.5 and (b) section of (a) membrane at high magnification (×5000). Fig. 5 TGA thermogrammes of PVdF with different TiO2 (Anatase P25 Degussa) contents: 0, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 1 TiO2/PVdF wt. ratio. Fig. 6 Rate of (a) BG and (b) IC degradations for membranes of different TiO2/PVdF ratios. Fig. 7 Kinetics of BG adsorption on PVdF microporous membrane, and on TiO2/PVdF composite membrane before and after a 5min-conditioning in ethanol. C 0: 10mg/L, T =23±1°C, V =10mL, natural pH. ♦ Composite membrane TiO2/PVdF after conditioning; ■ composite membrane TiO2/PVdF before conditioning; ▴ microporous membrane. Fig. 8 Kinetics of IC (a) and BG (b) adsorption onto TiO2/PVdF membrane in darkness. Volume of dye solution: 10mL; amount of the photocatalyst TiO2/PVdF: 0.1g; amount of the mixture of TiO2 Degussa P25 and PVdF; 50:50. ♦ 20mg/L; ■ 15mg/L; ▴10mg/L. Fig. 9 Kinetics of (a) BG depletion from aqueous dye solution by both adsorption and photocatalytic degradation with TiO2 and TiO2/PVdF membranes. C 0: 20mg/L, T =25±1°C, V =400mL, natural pH, overall composite catalyst content=1.25g/L and (b) IC depletion from aqueous dye solution by photocatalytic degradation with TiO2 and TiO2/PVdF membranes. C 0: 22mg/L, T =25±1°C, V =400mL, natural pH, overall composite catalyst content=1.25g/L. ♦ PVdF/TiO2; ▴irradiation alone ■ TiO2. Fig. 10 Pictures of the two faces of the composite membrane with adsorbed BG dye after irradiation. (a) Initial time; (b) exposed face; (c) non-exposed face. Table 1 Structure and some properties of PVdF. Developed formulae Molecular weight (g/mol) 254g/mol Glass transition temperature −38°C Melting temperature 160°C Amorphous density at 25°C 1.74g/cm3 Crystalline density at 25°C 2.00g/cm3 Intrinsic viscosity 0.881dL/g Table 2 Effect of TiO2 content on the mean pore diameter and porosity of the composite microporous PVdF/TiO2 membrane. IC BG k (mgL−1 min−1) 0.0605 0.0986 K (mgL−1) 0.046 0.028 R 2 0.99 0.98 Elaboration and study of poly(vinylidene fluoride)–anatase TiO2 composite membranes in photocatalytic degradation of dyes Ouafa Tahiri Alaoui a b ⁎ Quang Trong Nguyen a Chamekh Mbareck a Touria Rhlalou b a Polymers, Biopolymers and Surfaces Department, FRE 3101, CNRS, Rouen University, 76821 Mont-Saint-Aignan Cedex, France b Department of Chemistry, Hassan Ier University, Settat, Maroc ⁎ Corresponding author at: Polymers, Biopolymers and Surfaces Department, FRE 3101, CNRS, Rouen University, 76821 Mont-Saint-Aignan Cedex, France. Tel.: +33 235146696; fax: +33 235146704. Graphical abstract The adsorption capacity of the TiO2/PVdF membrane is enhanced by a prior conditioning in ethanol. The photocatalytic efficiency of TiO2 immobilized in PVdF was compared with that of the conventional TiO2 Degussa P25 catalyst. The rate of TiO2/PVdF membrane degradation photocatalytic was 6.1 and 2.4μmolL−1 min−1 for IC and BG respectively, against 8.7 and 5.9μmolL−1 min−1 for the P25 TiO2. Porous PVdF-based membranes filled with anatase (TiO2) nanocrystalline particles were prepared by using a new phase inversion technique for entrapment of TiO2. The prepared samples were characterized by scanning electron microscopy, thermal gravimetry analysis, and contact angle measurements. The SEM investigation showed a fair distribution in the membranes of the TiO2 particles, mainly in aggregate form. The best photocatalytic membrane had a pore size of 0.96μm, with a maximum porosity of 86% at 0.5 TiO2/PVdF weight ratio. The original porous TiO2/PVdF membranes showed a very weak degradation ability of dyes in an aqueous medium due to their poor wetting. We showed that a prior membrane conditioning in ethanol increased the membrane wetting, thus the dye degradation rate by making the TiO2 particles in the internal structure accessible to the external medium. The adsorption capacity of the TiO2/PVdF membrane was studied with the aqueous solutions of Brilliant Green (BG) and Indigo Carmin (IC) dyes, and the photocatalytic efficiency of TiO2 immobilized in PVdF was compared with that of the conventional TiO2 Degussa P25 catalyst. The rate of TiO2/PVdF membrane degradation photocatalytic was 6.1 and 2.4μmolL−1 min−1 for IC and BG respectively, against 8.7 and 5.9μmolL−1 min−1 for the P25 TiO2. The Langmuir-Hinshelwood model was adequate to describe the rate of dye degradation only when the amount of dyes adsorbed on photocatalytic material is significant. Keywords PVdF-TiO2 catalyst Photodegradation Dyes Microporous membranes Phase inversion 1 Introduction The treatment of colored wastewaters from textile or dye industry is a serious problem that attracts the attention of many researchers during the last decades. Among the methods used for dye elimination from wastewaters [1], the total degradation process by heterogenous photocatalysis appears to be highly attractive. Anatase-type TiO2 is the most often used photocatalyst due to its good photocatalytic activity, high stability, low-environment impact and low cost [2]. This catalyst can work under the form of powder suspended in a slurry or can be immobilized on various supports, such as glass, quartz or stainless steel [3]. In the case of a catalyst fixed on a carrier material, there is generally a significant reduction of the active surface accessible to components of the solution, which results in a loss of the material photocatalytic activity [4]. A suspension of catalyst has a higher degradation efficiency, but the catalyst particles needs to be separated from the treated water after the detoxification, and the small size of TiO2 particles (generally of nanometric size) makes its recovery from the reactor difficult. The sol–gel technique, which is currently used for anatase immobilization, required several carefully controlled steps, especially the heat treatment one [4]; this makes the catalyst preparation expensive. Some works delt with pre-formed anatase particles immobilized on silica [5,6]. Hydrophilic TiO2 particles were incorporated in filtration membranes to improve the membrane permeability and fouling resistance of by imparting hydrophilicity to their surface [7]. So far, few works were reported on the photodegradation by membrane-loaded anatase. Molinari et al. [8,9] studied photocatalytic membrane reactors with TiO2 deposited by filtration of TiO2 suspensions on polymer membranes. However, the deposited layer was not bound to the support and detached to the membrane surface during the operation. Later, they trapped the photocatalyst in cellulose triacetate membranes, but the trapped catalyst showed little photoactivity. Moreover, we found that the cellulosic membrane undergoes photocatalytic degradation when UV-irradiated in the presence of TiO2. The lack of interest in anatase-loaded membranes is probably due to such a risk of anatase-catalyzed degradation of the membrane matrix under lights [10]. Among polymer materials, only highly fluorinated polymers like poly(vinylidene fluoride) can resist to a photocatalytic degradation. TiO2 was incorporated into fluorinated-copolymer membranes to improve their mechanical and conductivity properties for lithium batteries applications [11]. Losito et al. [12] showed that anatase incorporation into dense poly(vinylidene fluoride) films photo-degraded effectively isoproturon, a pesticide, at high anatase–PVdF ratio, but not at a 1:1 ratio. This might be due to the dense structure of the materials, which limited the catalytic activity to the particles on the film surface. In this study, anatase was entrapped in the PVdF matrix of un-skinned microporous membranes by a proprietary phase inversion technique [13]. The latter technique is very convenient for obtaining microporous films by controlling preparation conditions such as the types of solvent and non-solvent in the polymer casting dope and their elimination process, the dope composition and eventually the crystallisation of the polymer matrix. We examined successively (i) the membrane morphology and physical properties, (ii) the effect of membrane conditioning in ethanol on the dye photo-degradation in the presence of the best composite membrane, (iii) the adsorption and the degradation capacities of the composite membranes towards Brilliant Green and Indigo Carmine dyes. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and products PVdF (Kynar 741) was supplied by Arkema Inc., Serquigny (France). Table 1 summarizes the structure and some properties of this product. Special titanium dioxide (TiO2), type P25, but with 98% anatase, was obtained from Degussa (Germany). The specific surface area of TiO2 was ca. 50m2/g. The size of individual particles was determined from X-ray diffraction data with Scherrer eqn. to be ca. 16nm. Brilliant Green (BG) (C27N2H34SO4) and Indigo Carmine (IC) (C16H8N2Na2O8S2) were used as a model compounds; their structure are shown in Figs. 1 and 2 . They were supplied by Standa laboratory and Sigma–Aldrich, respectively. Dye solutions were prepared by using ultra pure water (Milli Q with 18.6MΩcm). 2.2 PVdF-TiO2 membrane preparation For the microporous membrane preparation, a solution of 13wt.% PVdF (Kynar 741, from Arkema Inc.) was prepared by heating PVdF powder at 60°C during 2h in an acetone–butan-1ol mixture of 81:19wt. ratios under the mixture vapor pressure. The solution was rapidly cooled and an appropriate amount of anatase was dispersed under stirring. The dispersion was ultrasounded for 15min, then quickly spreaded with a Gardner-type knife onto a glass plate into a liquid film of thickness of ca. 200μm. The solvents of the liquid film were left to evaporate from the film free surface under atmospheric pressure at ambient temperature (ca. 25°C). The solvent evaporation, especially that of acetone, resulted in a fast phase separation in a concentrated polymer solution and a rapid setting of PVdF into a white microporous membrane (ca. 1–3min). An additional evaporation of the residual solvent (mainly butanol) was carried out in the ambient atmosphere or in a vented oven at 35°C. The TiO2-loaded dense and the asymmetric membranes were prepared from a solution of 15wt.% PVdF in dimethyl formamide (DMF) prepared by heating the mixture to 80°C. The solution was completely evaporated at 80°C then washed four-time with water to yield a TiO2-loaded dense membrane. The TiO2-loaded asymmetric membrane was obtained according to the widely used wet-phase inversion method [14,15] from the same polymer solution in DMF, with water as a coagulation medium. The thickness of these membranes was adjusted to be close to that of the microporous ones (60μm) by varying the thickness of the cast film. 2.3 Dye adsorption analysis and photo-degradation experiment The dye adsorption tests were performed using 10mL aqueous solutions at different concentrations (1, 2.5, 5, 10, 15, 20mg/L) of dye which were put into contact with ca. 0.1g of TiO2/PVdF membrane of 0.5 TiO2/PVdF ratio at 23±0.5°C until equilibrium. The amount of adsorbed dye was calculated using Eq. (1): (1) Q = ( C 0 − C ) V W where Q is the amount of adsorbed dye (mg/g), C 0 the initial dye concentration, C the dye concentration at fixed sorption times (mg/L), V the solution volume (L), and W the adsorbent weight (g). The photocatalytic activity of TiO2 films was tested by using degradation reactions of BG and IC dye solutions. The photodegradation reaction was carried out in a glass reactor containing 400mL of a model solution and a fixed amount of a photocatalyst, either as dispersed TiO2 powder or standing composite membrane. UV-irradiation was carried out with a Swig® black lamp (Bioblock) at 365nm wavelength. The nominal light flux of the lamp was 4750 lumens. The UV lamp was located at the top of the reactor, which was placed in a black box to prevent any external source of irradiation. The entire system was vented to keep the temperature at 26±1°C. Aqueous solutions of the BG and IC dyes were prepared at 20mg/L for the photodegradation with 2.5g/L of the TiO2/PVdF catalyst. Their pH were ca. 4.5 and 6, respectively. The free TiO2 powder was used as a reference for the comparison of the photocatalytic efficiency of the prepared catalyst. For each experiment, the aqueous suspensions of dye and the photocatalyst were stirred in the dark to ensure that the adsorption equilibrium was established prior to irradiation; 3mL of aliquots were taken from the reactor at different times by means of a 10mL syringe and were filtered through a Millipore filter (0.45μm) in the case of free TiO2 particles. The quantity of free TiO2 and that of TiO2 entrapped in the PVdF membrane were the same in the experiments. The reactor was operated under mild stirring, e.g. with a magnetic bar rotating at 100rpm. For the determination of concentration of dye, UV–Vis spectra were measured with a Kontron Uvicon 860 UV/Vis spectrophotometer, using a 1cm quartz cell. The kinetics of the reaction was obtained by monitoring the dye maximum absorbance, i.e. at 625nm for BG and 606nm for IC. 2.4 Characterisation of the composite membranes 2.4.1 Membrane structure analyses The surface morphology of TiO2/PVdF films was observed by using a scanning electron microscope (SEM, Jeol JSM35 CF, Japan). For the cross-section SEM images, samples were fractured in liquid nitrogen. The samples were coated with a thin sputtered gold layer under vacuum. The mean pore diameter was determined by averaging the diameter of 20 pores with the Saisam software (Microvision Instruments, France). The contact angle of the membrane surface was measured with a multi-purpose optical instrument (Multiskop, from Optrel, Germany). The membrane samples were conditioned by dipping a sample into distilled water, another sample into ethanol for 5min, and then rinsed with water. The samples were wiped with paper tissue then dried in ambient air before the experiments for 10min. The reported values were the average of the contact angles of five different measurements with a standard deviation of 0.5°. The overall TiO2/PVdF ratio in the composite membranes was determined from the weight of the inorganic anatase phase left after a complete pyrolysis of the polymer phase in samples of known weight, by thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA7 from Perkin-Elmer). Practically, a sample of ca. 10mg of membrane was heated from room temperature to 800°C at a rate of 10°C/min. The total degradation of PVdF was checked with pure PVdF membranes. 2.4.2 Measurement of the overall membrane porosity The overall porosity of the membranes was determined from the weight at 20°C of the dry membrane sample of known dimensions and that of the same sample after equilibrium in butan-1ol and surface liquid elimination with a cellulose paper. We have first checked that butan-1ol wetted well PVdF without swelling (i.e. negligible absorption by the polymer) so that it can fill all pores of the membrane inner structure after wetting equilibrium. The difference in the volumes of the butanol-wetted and the dry membranes represents the pore volume, whose fraction with respect to the membrane volume is the membrane porosity. We assumed that all matters kept their specific gravity unchanged in the (wetted) composite membranes, i.e. there was no volume contraction upon mixing. The values of the specific gravity taken for the porosity calculation were 0.81, 4.05, and 1.77g/cm3 for butan-1ol, anatase, and PVdF, respectively. For the PVdF phase, we neglected the change in its specific gravity due to the PVdF crystallinity change. The porosity (P) was determined using Eq. (2): (2) P = ( W 1 − W 2 ) / D b [ ( W 1 − W 2 ) / D b + W P / D p + W Ti O 2 / D Ti O 2 ] where W 1 and W 2 are the weight of membrane immersed in butan1-ol and that of the initial membrane, respectively, W P is the weight of polymer, W Ti O 2 is the weight of titanium dioxide, D b is the butan-1ol density, D p is the polymer density and D Ti O 2 is the titanium dioxide density. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Morphology and characteristics of composite TiO2/PVdF membranes 3.1.1 Suitability of the techniques used for preparation of TiO2-loaded membrane The microporous PVdF-based membrane was prepared according to a proprietary technique protected by a French patent [12]. The technique allowed us to obtain a symmetric microporous membrane in a very simple and fast process. So far, there are no comparative studies on the photocatalytic performances of TiO2 in polymer of different physical structure. Preliminary tests were thus required to select the suitable structure for TiO2 immobilization. For this the same content in photocatalyst particles were loaded into PVdF dense, asymmetric, and symmetric microporous PVdF films, according to the procedure described in Section 2.2. When evaluated by means of the photodegradation test with Indigo Carmine, no noticeable photodegradation was observed for the TiO2-loaded dense membrane, while the asymmetric membrane showed a much smaller photodegradation rate than the un-skinned microporous membrane (smaller than a half of that of the microporous membrane). We infer that the mass transfer of the dye molecule towards TiO2 particles, which were embedded in PVdF, was greatly hindered in the case of the dense PVdF membrane, and partially hindered by the dense skin of the asymmetric membrane. Although asymmetric membranes, from the membrane process point of view, have several advantages over symmetric ones (like high flux, low in-depth fouling, back-flushable…), the would be less suitable as membranes for solid-catalyst immobilization. In the case of these catalyst-born asymmetric membranes, the photocatalytic activity is more important than the separation properties which are not put in used in catalytic reactions with immersed membranes. We also tested the TiO2-loaded microporous membranes in a dye-solution filtration through the solution pre-equilibrated membrane and observed that the dye content did not change in the membrane filtration, i.e. these membranes could not remove the dye in a direct filtration operation. The highest efficiency of the un-skinned symmetric membrane can be explained by the lowest mass transfer resistances for the reactant and product diffusion from/to the external phase towards the catalyst particles inside the membrane. For microporous membranes, the mass transfer mainly occurs by convection and diffusion in the liquid-filled pores, without limitations by the slow diffusion through the dense skin. It should be noted that a loss of TiO2 of ca. 10wt.% occurred in the water-coagulation step of the conventional technique of asymmetric membrane preparation. The lost in TiO2 nanoparticles was due to the leak of the TiO2 particles carried with the phase-separated water-rich droplets that escaped out of the nascent membrane by the end of the coagulation step. Such a loss in catalyst particles did not occur in the patented technique of un-skinned symmetric membrane preparation. Another advantage of this technique of microporous PVdF membrane preparation resides in the high rate of membrane formation (within few minutes). The conventional coagulation technique can only yield a symmetric structure in a very long process (hours) of coagulation in a very ‘soft’ non-solvent bath [15–17]. Moreover, the use of an organic solvent like octanol, or a mixture of water with a large proportion of a polymer solvent, for the soft coagulation bath [15,17] makes the membrane manufacture by the coagulation technique less nature-friendly than our patented technique. 3.1.2 Membrane morphology and porosity The preliminary data in Section 3.1.1 suggest a large effect of the membrane pore size and morphology on the catalyst efficiency after immobilization in a membrane. Fig. 3a and b shows the surface of samples of a pure PVdF membrane and a TiO2/PVdF composite membrane, respectively. Numerous oblong/circular pore openings are visible on the membrane surfaces, with mean sizes of ca. 0.43 and 0.96μm for the pure membrane and the composite membrane of 0.5 TiO2/PVdF ratio in the casting dope, respectively. One can see that the surface pores open downwards deep into the inner structure, i.e. the surface pores are not dead-ended, but connected to the pore network (Fig. 4 ). The pore morphology is different from that commonly observed in the membranes prepared according to the other techniques; it is not of honey-comb type and does not contain finger-like macrovoids. Fig. 3 shows an increase in the number of anatase aggregates on the surface with the anatase content, but the particles seem to be blocked on the surface by the intertwined polymer ribbons. Some subtle changes occurred in the morphology of the polymer phase on the membrane surface with the anatase content: (Fig. 3). The section of the PVDF membranes with/without TiO2 particles (Fig. 4a and b) shows a lace-like structure for the “continuous” polymer phase, with intersecting cavities of micrometer size, in which aggregated anatase particles are entrapped. The enlarged SEM micrograph (Fig. 4b) shows granules of hundred nanometers in the anatase phase. These granules were primary aggregates (Fig. 4b), not individual TiO2 particles, whose size was much smaller (ca. 16nm, as determined from X-ray diffraction data). From this SEM cliche, one can expect the surface of the granules to be effective in catalytic action, as the granules are accessible, i.e. not covered by the polymer (Fig. 4b). With the incorporation of a small proportion of anatase particles in the casting dope, the mean pore size of the obtained membranes (estimated from SEM micrographs) is first reduced, then increases with the particle content, and goes through a maximum at a TiO2/PVdF ratio of 0.5 (Table 2 ). In fact, the anatase aggregates appeared to be well entrapped in the ribbon network that forms the pores, and were stable in the use of the membranes in reactors. The overall porosity of the composite membranes, calculated from the weight of a pore-filling liquid, goes through a maximum with this ratio (Table 2). Thus, the anatase granules, which are randomly distributed in the membrane volume, appear to impart an increased porosity and pore size (Table 2 and Fig. 3) in the intermediate range of TiO2/PVdF ratio, and a retention in the membrane pores in spite of the large size of the pores (ca. 0.4–0.96μm) compared to that of individual anatase particles. The increase in porosity with the TiO2/PVdF ratio would be partially due to an anatase-promoted increase in the number of the nuclei of polymer-lean phase, which ultimately become the membrane pores. The higher porosity obtained with the incorporation of larger proportion of anatase particles would also be due to the presence of inter-granular spaces in the embedded anatase aggregates (Fig. 4). The decrease in porosity beyond a TiO2/PVdF ratio of 0.5 can be explained by an insufficient polymer material to form the polymer scaffold of the porous membrane (Fig. 3c and d), which leads to a system collapse, i.e. a decrease in the porosity and the pore size of the whole structure. The TGA study of the composite membranes showed that PVdF started to decompose at ca. 382°C to become total at ca. 600°C (Fig. 5 ). It also indicated that the TiO2/PVdF ratios in the casting dopes and in the final membranes were the same within experimental errors, thus confirming the entrapment without loss of catalytic particles in a microporous polymer matrix (Fig. 6 ). 3.2 Properties of anatase-loaded membranes in contact with dye solutions 3.2.1 TiO2/PVdF ratio for maximum rate of dye degradation The initial rate of degradation of IG dye in standard conditions (1g of membranes immersed in 400mL of solution of 20mg/L of IC or BG, respectively, at 25±1°C) was measured with all the prepared TiO2/PVdF membranes. Figs. 7 and 8 show a maximum in the dye degradation rate, whose value of the TiO2/PVdF ratio, 0.5, is the same as the maximum of membrane porosity and pore size (Table 2). The similarity in the variations of the rate of photo-chemical reactions and the porosity and pore size of the composite membrane suggests that the reaction kinetics were controlled by the kinetics of product transport through the porous structure that entraps the photo-catalyst. As there was no liquid flow through the membrane in the immersed-membrane reactor, the maximum in the reaction rate would also be that in the molecular transport of different species by diffusion, from the external phase, in the liquid-filled pores of the membranes. Due to their best performances in photocatalysis, the membrane having a TiO2/PVdF ratio of 0.5 was selected for further studies on the membrane properties. 3.3 Dye adsorption 3.3.1 Effect the ethanol conditioning on dye adsorption in membranes The surface tension of water may hinder access for the dissolved products to the catalyst particles inside hydrophobic membranes. The complex nature and morphology of the prepared membranes requires an experimental study of the contact angle with water. A way to improve the membrane wettability is to pre-condition the membrane with ethanol. Thus, the hydrophilicity of three membranes, non-conditioned pure PVdF, ethanol-conditioned and non-conditioned TiO2/PVdF, were characterized through the measurement of their contact angle with water. The contact angle of water with the membrane surface decreased from 81° to 70° when the pristine composite membrane (of TiO2/PVdF ratio of 0.5) is pre-conditioned in ethanol, while that of the pure PVdF membrane ethanol-conditioned and non-conditioned was 0° and 78° respectively. The values of the contact angle for the microporous PVdF membranes are consistent with those reported by Feng et al. [18]. While PVdF is a hydrophobic polymer (like other fluorinated polymers), anatase is known as a highly hydrophilic material: its deposited layer was reported to have a contact angle smaller than 5°. It may appear surprising that TiO2 did not improve the hydrophilicity of its blend with microporous PVdF. The absence of wetting improvement could be explained by an effective entrapping of anatase particles by the polymer on the external surface. If the external liquid poorly wets the membrane surface, it will not be able to come into contact with the anatase particles in the internal structure, thus there will be no wetting improvement (Fig. 3). The absence of wetting improvement in the composite (non-conditioned) membranes can also be explained by the “lotus effect” on the contact angle: water drops sit suspended on top of the micrometer-size bumps of the rough surface, due to pinning effect [19]. When the ethanol-conditioned membrane is put into contact with water, the latter can penetrate into pores via the ethanol-wetted polymer phase, and the membrane remains wetted with water, even when ethanol is washed out in further rinsing steps. The hydrophilic anatase particles in the membrane pores were not covered by PVdF (Fig. 4b), thus could be easily wetted by water. During a rinsing procedure or a mild evaporation of interstitial water, it is possible that the ethanol-induced orientation of chemical groupings on the surface and on the pore walls was maintained in the same state and caused the decrease in the contact angle with water. Upon complete drying, hydrophobic groups should be re-oriented outward, as we observed again a fully hydrophobic behavior of the membrane upon thorough drying. Note that the change in the wetting of the whole membrane structure by water in the ethanol-conditioning process was totally reversible. 3.3.2 Effect of ethanol conditioning on dye adsorption and water permeation Tests of dye adsorption at equilibrium were performed on the composite membranes before and after its rapid conditioning in ethanol (by immersing the membranes 5min in ethanol, then rinsing them with water). Fig. 7 shows a large increase in the amount of BG adsorbed in the TiO2/PVdF composite membrane when the membrane TiO2/PVdF is shortly conditioned in ethanol before the adsorption test. Such a change in the membrane behavior cannot be due to a change in the membrane structure in the contact with ethanol, which is a non-solvent that does not swell PVdF. The fast conditioning and rinsing with water would leave the bulk of the material unchanged, as the contact time was too short for the non-swelling liquid to change the chain organization. The only possible change was the better wetting of the external and internal surfaces after the membrane contact with the wetting liquid (ethanol), which was proven by the decrease in the contact angle with water. Thus, the dye molecules freely accessed to the internal structure and adsorb onto PVdF and anatase particles, according to their specific affinity. This explains why the non-conditioned composite membrane adsorbed much less dyes – only on the external surface –, than the conditioned one – on the surface and on the pore surface – (Table 3 ). The better dye sorption by the non-conditioned composite membrane with respect to the microporous PVdF membrane (Table 3) can be explained by a larger dye sorption ability of anatase particles at the interfacial area in-between the polymer and anatase. In fact, the dye adsorption must occur on the surface of anatase particles via micro-cracks at the anatase particles–polymer interface, since there is no interaction expected between anatase and PVdF, a polymer known for its weak attraction force to other matters. It should be noted that other water-soluble wetting liquids (methanol, isopropanol, and acetone) gave similar results when tested for the membrane conditioning. Anatase particles with their polar and eventually ionized OH groups on surface would help the external aqueous media to get into the conditioned-membrane structure, making possible the sorption on the particles. 3.3.3 Kinetics and sorption levels at equilibrium The kinetics of adsorption for the two dyes is shown in Fig. 8 for different initial dye concentrations (in the 5–20ppm range). Whatever the initial dye concentration, the steady state of adsorption was reached within 1 hr for BG and 10min for IC. These times were selected for the pre-equilibrium period in the dark before UV-irradiation, to make sure that the degradation was initiated after adsorption equilibrium. The following linearized Langmuir and Freundlich equations were used to fit the experimental data: 1/q =(1/K ads q max)(1/C eq)+1/q max and log q =log F +(1/n)log C eq, respectively, where q is the amount of dye adsorbed on the photocatalyst in mg/g, C eq is the dye concentration in solution at equilibrium in mg/L, K ads the equilibrium constant, q max the maximum amount of dye adsorbed on the adsorbent; K ads, and q max represent the parameters of the Langmuir eqn., while F and 1/n those of the Freundlich eqn. The values of the parameters of the Freundlich equation (F and 1/q) and the parameters of Langmuir equation (K ads, and q max) were calculated from the intercept and the slope of the linear least square regression line. The linear regression of the Langmuir model for BG and IC adsorption gave a negative value for the 1/q max term. As already reported [20], the Langmuir model appears not adapted for the representation of the experimental BG and IC isotherms. The calculated values of the Freundlich parameters are given in Table 4 . The TiO2/PVdF membrane had low adsorption (Table 3) levels for IC dye compared with BG dye, because of the intrinsically low sorption ability of indigo carmine in aqueous media (Table 3); its two sulfonate groupings impart strong interactions with water, while its two hydroxyl groups are involved in intramolecular hydrogen bonds, thus not available for interactions with other matters. The amount of IC dye adsorbed on anatase particles was reported to correspond to a surface coverage of 0.13 molecules per nm2 [21], that is ca. 3% of titania OH surface groups (5 molecules per nm2) [22]. The calculated amount of IC dye adsorbed on anatase particles entrapped in the PVdF microporous membrane is ca. 4.5×10−3 mg/g; this low coverage of the entrapped particles suggests a partial hindrance of the anatase-particle surface by the polymer ribbons that are close to the particle aggregates. Vautier et al. [21] suggested that IC molecules adsorb perpendicularly to the particle surface via one of the sulfonate groups of the dye. We speculate that BG molecules adsorb onto the anatase surface in a similar way, but via the quaternary ammonium group of the dye. Such an adsorption by strong interactions between the positively charged groups on the BG molecules and the groups with negative charges (ionized OH), or rich in electron (non-ionized OH) on the anatase particles explains the ten-fold higher adsorption level for BG dye (Table 3) on the conditioned composite membrane compared with IC dye. The low adsorption levels of both dyes on the membrane PVdF ribbons (Table 3) suggest a similar adsorption mechanism, e.g. adsorption by hydrophobic interactions between PVdF and the aromatic rings in the dye molecules. 3.4 Application of TiO2/PVdF membrane to the photocatalytic degradation of IC and BG The photocatalytic activity of TiO2 immobilized in the microporous PVdF membrane was compared with that of the anatase Degussa catalyst. For this, the photocatalytic degradation of BG and IC at a concentration ≈20mg/L was studied in the presence of the catalyst at a content of 1.25g/L for pure TiO2 powder, or 2.5g/L for the composite membrane of 0.5 TiO2/PVdF ratio (i.e. 1.25g/L of anatase). A blank experiment (irradiation of dye solutions without TiO2) indicated an absence of UV action on the BG degradation, even after a long period of time. Consequently, the decrease in the dye concentration in the presence of the membrane-supported TiO2, after adsorption/desorption equilibrium, was entirely due to photocatalytic reactions. The dye disappearance kinetics reported in Fig. 9 indicate that after 7.5h of irradiation for BG, the dye degradation ratio was about 81% for TiO2/PVdF and 97% for TiO2, and after 5h of irradiation for IC, the dye degradation ratio was about 89% for TiO2/PVdF and 97% for TiO2. Note that the composite membrane could be easily taken out of the reactor and repeatedly used in photodegradation, contrary to free anatase particles. The rate of degradation of IC is higher than that for BG in the presence of TiO2 (8.76 and 5.9μmolL−1 h−1 respectively) and TiO2/PVdF catalyst (6.15 and 2.46μmolL−1 h−1 respectively). The Langmuir-Hinshelwood model (L-H) was used to analyse the photo-oxidation kinetics of the two dyes. The L-H model can be written as follows: (3) r = k K e C 1 + K e C where k represents the kinetics constant, K e represents the adsorption constant and C the concentration in the solution. The plot of 1/r against 1/C 0 is a straight line, indicating a Langmuir-Hinshelwood behavior for the photodegradation of these dyes in the presence of the anatase catalyst. The kinetics constants of the L-H model for BG and the IC are given in Table 5 . As a membrane forms a barrier for mass transfer in space, one may raise the question whether the TiO2/PVdF composite membrane also forms a barrier for the light in the photocatalytic reaction. Fig. 10 shows that when the membrane with adsorbed BG is irradiated from one side, the dye-discoloration rate is higher for the exposed face than for the opposite face. Although there is a difference in the dye-degradation rate for the two faces, the photocatalytic reaction did occur on the non-exposed face. This could be explained by the transparency of PVdF to visible and near-UV, and by the fact that the light scattered by the anatase particles and the PVdF ribbons can be used by the catalyst particles behind. 4 Conclusion Anatase/PVdF microporous membranes were fabricated using a new phase inversion method. The composite microporous membranes were characterized by different techniques; they exhibited a high porosity and had well inter-connected pores of sub-micron mean size, in which anatase-particle aggregates were well entrapped. The polymer formed the pores with their ribbons that entrapped well anatase aggregates. The pore size and membrane porosity went through a maximum with the increase in the TiO2 content in the liquid casting dope. The original composite membranes had negligible photocatalytic activity with regards to dyes in aqueous media because of their poor wetting. A prior membrane conditioning in ethanol increased the membrane wetting, thus the dye degradation rate by making TiO2 particles in the internal structure accessible to the external medium. The adsorption capacity of TiO2/PVdF membranes was higher for Brilliant Green than for Indigo Carmin dyes in aqueous solutions. The use of such TiO2/PVdF microporous membranes enables an efficient photocatalytic degradation/mineralization of dye without additional separation steps for the catalyst particles. coredata.dc:description: Porous PVdF-based membranes filled with anatase (TiO2) nanocrystalline particles were prepared by using a new phase inversion technique for entrapment of TiO2. The prepared samples were characterized by scanning electron microscopy, thermal gravimetry analysis, and contact angle measurements. The SEM investigation showed a fair distribution in the membranes of the TiO2 particles, mainly in aggregate form. The best photocatalytic membrane had a pore size of 0.96μm, with a maximum porosity of 86% at 0.5 TiO2/PVdF weight ratio. The original porous TiO2/PVdF membranes showed a very weak degradation ability of dyes in an aqueous medium due to their poor wetting. We showed that a prior membrane conditioning in ethanol increased the membrane wetting, thus the dye degradation rate by making the TiO2 particles in the internal structure accessible to the external medium. The adsorption capacity of the TiO2/PVdF membrane was studied with the aqueous solutions of Brilliant Green (BG) and Indigo Carmin (IC) dyes, and the photocatalytic efficiency of TiO2 immobilized in PVdF was compared with that of the conventional TiO2 Degussa P25 catalyst. The rate of TiO2/PVdF membrane degradation photocatalytic was 6.1 and 2.4μmolL−1 min−1 for IC and BG respectively, against 8.7 and 5.9μmolL−1 min−1 for the P25 TiO2. The Langmuir-Hinshelwood model was adequate to describe the rate of dye degradation only when the amount of dyes adsorbed on photocatalytic material is significant.
coredata.dc:title: Elaboration and study of poly(vinylidene fluoride)–anatase TiO2 composite membranes in photocatalytic degradation of dyes
